note.p: Kinloch Falconer was active in Democratic politics in Mississippi during Reconstruction and served as Mississippi’s secretary of state in 1878.

Born on October 28, 1838, Falconer grew up in Holly Springs, Mississippi. As a young man he worked at the Southern Herald (his father’s newspaper) and attended the University of Mississippi, graduating in 1860 on the eve of the Civil War. When the war broke out, Falconer enlisted in the 9th Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Recognized for his intelligence and writing ability, Falconer was soon promoted and moved to administrative and staff work, first serving as the private secretary and then adjutant general for Confederate General Braxton Bragg. Later he served as a staff officer for Confederate General Joseph E. Johnston during the Atlanta Campaign in the summer of 1864.

After the defeat of the Confederacy, Falconer returned to Mississippi and reentered the newspaper business, becoming editor of the Holly Springs Reporter. He began fostering an interest state politics and unsuccessfully ran for lieutenant governor as a Democrat under Benjamin G. Humphreys in 1868. In 1870, Falconer stepped away from editorial duties at the Reporter to practice law full time. He continued participating in Democratic politics and in 1877 was elected secretary of state. He entered that office in January 1878. However, only a few months later, a yellow fever epidemic struck parts of Mississippi. Falconer’s brother and father were stricken by the mosquito-borne disease. He went to Holly Springs to aid in their care, but both men died. Falconer himself then came down with the disease and died on September 23, 1878. He is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(The Daily Clarion, Meridian, MS, June 22, 1864; The Grenada Sentinel, Grenada, MS, May 16, 1868; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, February 3, 1870; The. Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, November 6, 1878; Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: William E. Hunt was a Confederate officer, planter, Sheriff of Washington County, and U.S. Consul to China during President Grover Cleveland's administration (1885-1889 and 1893-1897).

Born on April 23, 1840 in Frankfort, Kentucky, Hunt enlisted into the Confederate Army on March 9, 1862. He was promoted to the rank of Captain of Company D of the Twenth-Eighth Mississippi Cavalry and was discharged on May 22, 1865 after the Confederate Army surrendered. From 1876 to 1903, he served multiple terms as Sheriff of Washington County, Mississippi, and he served as the U.S. Consul to China during President Cleveland's administration. He also owned two plantations in Mississippi, La Grange Plantation and Montrose Plantation.

Hunt was married to Maria (Crittenden) Hunt, who preceded him in death in 1909. The pair had six children, including four girls and two boys. William E. Hunt died on February 18, 1915 in Greenville, Mississippi. He was buried in the Greenville Cemetery.
(FindaGrave; The Weekly Democrat Times, January 29, 1876; The Weekly Democrat Times, October 10, 1903)

John Marshall Stone served as governor of Mississippi two separate times, from 1876 to 1882 and from 1890 to 1896.

Born in Milan, Tennessee, on March 29, 1876, Stone grew up mostly in poverty but worked for his education and eventually became a school teacher. He moved to Mississippi in the mid-1850s and found work as a railroad station agent at Iuka, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Stone joined the Confederate army. He was placed in command of Company K of the 2nd Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Proving capable in battle during campaigns in Virginia, he was promoted in 1862 to colonel of the regiment and received high praise from his superiors during the rest of the war. Stone led his regiment until near the end of the war, when he was captured in North Carolina and sent to Ohio as a prisoner.

Upon his release after the Civil War, Stone returned to Mississippi and resumed his work with the Mississippi and Ohio Railroad at Iuka. He married Mary G. Coman in 1872 and had two children, both of whom died before adulthood. Stone and his wife also adopted and raised three of his nephews.

He entered politics in 1869, winning election to the Mississippi state senate as a Democrat. In 1873 and 1874, Democrats in Mississippi gained majority power following campaigns of voter intimidation and violence against African Americans and Republicans. Stone worked his way to president pro tempore of the Senate during this period. In 1876, the Democrat majority in the state legislature carried out an impeachment campaign against top Republican officials, including Governor Adelbert Ames and Lieutenant Governor Alexander K. Davis. When Davis was impeached and Ames was forced to resign to avoid a costly lawsuit against politically-driven impeachment charges, Stone became next in line for governor. He was sworn into office in March 1876.

Stone served as acting-governor for a year and a half and then won the gubernatorial election in 1877, running as the sole candidate. He lost reelection in 1881 to Robert Lowry, but retained his interest in the governor’s office and ran again—and won—in 1889. Mississippi adopted a new constitution in 1890, which in part extended Stone’s gubernatorial term until 1896 to aid the transition of new policies. The new constitution prohibited successive gubernatorial terms. Thus, Stone could not run for immediate reelection. Upon leaving office, he received an appointment as president of the Mississippi Agricultural and Mechanical College (now Mississippi State University) in Starkville. He died in 1900 and is buried at Oak Grove Cemetery in Iuka, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Dan Sansing, “John Marshall Stone: Thirty-first and Thirty-third Governor of Mississippi: 1876-1882; 1890–1896,” Mississippi History Now)

Augustus Hill Garland was a lawyer and a politician, serving in the Confederate Congress, as the Governor of Arkansas from 1874 to 1877, as a U.S. Senator from 1877 to 1885, and as the U.S. Attorney General from 1885 to 1889.

Born on June 11, 1832 in Covington, Tennessee, Garland moved to Lost Prairie, Arkansas with his family while he was an infant. He graduated from St. Joseph's College in Bardstown, Kentucky in 1849, and in 1853, he opened a law firm with his stepfather Thomas Hubbard in Washington County, Arkansas. Three years later, Garland moved to Little Rock, Arkansas, where he opened a law firm with Ebenezer Cummins. He was also active in state politics, and he was a vocal opponent of secession until President Abraham Lincoln's call for troops.
During the Civil War, Garland served in the Confederate Congress. He was a Representative for Arkansas until November 1864 when he became a Confederate Senator.

After the war, Garland returned to Arkansas to assist in the state's Reconstruction. In July 1865, U.S. President Andrew Johnson pardoned Garland, and Garland returned to his law practice. His most prominent case was the Supreme Court Case Ex parte Garland. After the Civil War, the U.S. Congress passed a law banning former members of the Confederate government or military from arguing cases before the court. In January 1867, by a vote of 5-4, Garland won his argument that this law was unconsititutional.

Afterwards, Garland focused his attention on politics, and he was elected as a U.S. Senator for Arkansas in 1867 but was denied his seat due to his former role in the Confederate government. He spent the following years practicing law and engaging in local politics. In 1874, he was elected as the state's Governor. One of his primary contributions as Governor was in reducing the state's war debt. He also took an active role in improving the state's education system. This included establishing the Branch Normal College (today's University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff) to make education more accesible to Black men.

Garland's term as Governor ended in 1877, and he served as a U.S. senator from 1877 to 1885. In 1885, he resigned this position to serve as the U.S. Attorney General under President Grover Cleveland. He served until 1889, at which point he retired from public office. Garland remained in Washington D.C., where he continued to practice law before the Supreme Court.

Garland was married to Sarah Virginia (Sanders) Garland, who preceded him in death in 1877. The pair had nine children, including three sons and one daughter who lived to adulthood. On January 26, 1899, Augustus Hill Garland had a stroke while arguing a case before the U.S. Supreme Court. He died just a few hours later. His body was returned to Arkansas, and he was buried in the Mount Holly Cemetery in Little Rock, Pulaski County, Arkansas.
(Encyclopedia of Arkansas; Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: William Pitt Kellogg was governor of Louisiana and a U.S. Senator during the Reconstruction era.

Born on December 8, 1830, in Orwell, Vermont, Kellogg moved to Illinois as a young man and taught school. In the 1850s he moved to Illinois and became an attorney, meeting fellow lawyer Abraham Lincoln. When Lincoln entered the U.S. presidency in 1861, Kellogg received an appointment as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court in Nebraska Territory. He only briefly held that position before volunteering for military service and served as an officer in the Seventh Illinois Cavalry Regiment. By 1862, he had received a promotion to colonel, but resigned that summer due to health problems and returned to Nebraska to resume his duties in the territorial Supreme Court.

In 1865, Kellogg received an appointment as the federal customs collector in New Orleans, Louisiana. He held that position until 1868, when he was elected to the U.S. Senate for Louisiana, upon that state’s readmission to the Union. In 1872, Kellogg ran for governor of Louisiana as a Republican. Upon winning a disputed election, he resigned his Senate seat. Democrats, and even some Republicans, challenged Kellogg’s legitimacy in office, however he remained governor largely through the support of President Ulysses S. Grant. The Louisiana legislature impeached Kellogg in 1876, but the state Senate did not convict him.

In 1876, Kellogg again ran for the U.S. Senate. He won, despite severe opposition by conservative white Democrats. He served until 1883, but did not run for reelection due to the collapse of the Republican Party in Louisiana and the resurgence of Democratic control. However, Kellogg managed to secure enough support to win a U.S. House of Representatives seat during the 1882 election and served in that role from 1883 to 1885.
After his Congressional career, Kellogg retired in Washington, D.C. He died on August 10, 1918. He was married to Mary Ellen Wills. Kellogg is buried in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

Currently located in Washington County, Greenville was founded in 1824 in what was then Yazoo County. Washington County was created on January 29, 1827, and in 1844, Greenville became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.

Operating at the state level, the Arkansas Executive Department was established by the Arkansas Constitution (1836) on January 30, 1836 and is headed by the Office of the Governor. All agencies and offices within the Department are subordinate to the Governor. (Encyclopedia of Arkansas; Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Louisiana State Executive Department was established by Article 3 of the Louisiana Constitution in 1812 and serves as part of the executive branch of the Louisiana state government. It is led by the Louisiana State Governor, who directly presides over the Cabinet. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

div.p:
Office of W. E. HUNT,
Sheriff of Washington County, Mississippi.

To his Excellency J. M. Stone
Gov. of Miss.—

Dear Sir, please find certified copies of indictments vs Simon Redick, John Sweeney and Andrew Ivery, have ask that you make requisition on the Governor of Arkansas for Simon Redick, and on the Gov. of La for Andrew Ivery and John Sweeney
Oblige most respcly yr obt servt

W E Hunt Shff
Washington Co. Miss

From W. S. Hunt, Shff.
Address Greenville, Miss.
Dated August 19th, 1876.
Received " 21st, "
Answered " 22d, "
Encloses indictments for Requisitions for arrest of Simon Redick, John Sweeney and Andrew Ivery.
